Info: A new hobby is being explored in garages across America: microcomputers. These early personal computers (PCs) are not much more than kit-assembled metal boxes that perform basic math and a few simple games. Inspired by an article about the Altair 8800 computer from MITS, Bill Gates and Paul Allen develop the first microcomputer programming language, Altair BASIC, and begin an extraordinary, history-making journey.
Microsoft rents its first office in an Albuquerque, New Mexico office building.
In August 1977, the company formed an agreement with ASCII Magazine in Japan, resulting in its first international office of ASCII Microsoft.
At the end of this year, Microsoft packs up its headquarters for the move to Bellevue, Washington and year end sales exceed $1 million.

By 1980, Microsoft formed it’s Consumer Products Division and is adapting software like Adventure, Typing Tutor and Olympic Decathlon for various microcomputers like the TRS-80.
In August, IBM ships its new PC running MS-DOS, Microsoft Basic and Microsoft Cobol and other software is also available, which becomes the new standard for the industry.
Microsoft enters the business productivity category with Multiplan, followed shortly by Microsoft Word which happens to work with the new Microsoft Mouse released in early 1983.
Paul Allen resigned from Microsoft in 1983 after developing Hodgkin's disease.
The graphical user interface (GUI) begins to take hold when Apple releases its Macintosh computer, and Microsoft ships several applications for it as a key partner at release time.
In November, Windows, Microsoft’s GUI platform finally hits the market after Excel for the Macintosh ups the spreadsheet ante.
Big changes in this year when Microsoft moves to its new corporate headquarters in Redmond, WA and goes public at a $21 per share price.
Microsoft released its version of OS/2 to original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) on April 2, 1987.
Since 1988, Microsoft's use of per processor licenses has increased.
The first version of Office hits the market, creating a new category “suite” for productivity software.
Windows 3.0 ships in the spring and includes the free and addicting game of solitaire.

Visual Basic code-named Thunder launches, pioneering the graphical application development environment category, and making it even easier to develop Windows software. This is also the year when Rick Rashid joins Microsoft to start a new group called Microsoft Research, tasked with expanding the reach of personal computing.
Access and FoxPro databases for Windows ships, making it easier for non-developers to manage their data.

Microsoft introduces its Home brand of software, including reference titles like Encarta, Dogs and Dinosaurs, and its first software created especially for Kids, Creative Writer and Fine Artist. Also, Microsoft gets serious about the enterprise market, shipping Windows NT and Windows NT Advance Server.
For the first time, Microsoft launches an advertising campaign for the all-up brand, titled “Where do you want to go today?”.

Windows 95 and Office 95 ship this year in a whirlwind of mainstream publicity. MSN ships as a Windows 95 option, and Internet explorer 1.0 ships as part of Windows 95 Plus! Pack. By October, 7 million units of Windows 95 have sold, and by November, more than 500,000 users have signed up for MSN.

As 1995 draws to a close, Microsoft hosts Internet Strategy Day, announcing its commitment to adding Internet capabilities into all of its products. Microsoft ships Office 97 and the first version of Exchange Server, acquires FrontPage and Internet Gaming Zone, and launches MSNBC.

The ActiMates Interactive Toy line is launched, with its first character, Barney the Dinosaur, later followed by Arthur, D.W. and the Teletubbies. 1997 was also all about content and connections as Microsoft acquires Hotmail and WebTV, invests $150 million in Apple Computer and launches Sidewalk.com city guides, which were developed in its Seattle office and sold to CitySearch in 1999.
Windows 98 launched simultaneously in more than 40 countries. It features support for a new technology, USB.
Internet Explorer 5.0 launches with more than one million downloads in the first week. Office 2000 is also released and mediation begins in the antitrust suit filed a year before.
Steve Ballmer replaced Gates as CEO in 2000.
This year sees the launch of the Windows XP Operating System and the Office XP office suite. Microsoft also launches the new Xbox gaming console with a five-game line-up including Halo.
Bill Gates outlines Microsoft’s commitment to Trustworthy Computing in a publicly shared memo to all employees.
This year sees the release of Windows Server 2003 and Office 2003, which includes a brand new productivity application called OneNote.
Halo 2.0 is released and sells 2.4 million units in the first 24 hours.

The Xbox 360 games console is launched as a 24-hour party in the Mojave desert. At the same time, Office and Windows head toward the cloud with preview of their Live versions. This years also sees the granting of Microsoft’s 5,000th patent.
Microsoft in 2006 released the Zune series of digital media players, a successor of its previous software platform Portable Media Center.
Windows Vista and Office 2007 are released to continue the evolution of both Operating System and office productivity suite.
Bill Gates transitioned to spending the majority of his time at his foundation.
Some products get a major overhaul and other efforts are brand new, as Microsoft launches Windows 7, Bing search engine, Azure and opens the very first Microsoft Retail Stores.
Microsoft pioneers human computer interaction with the Kinect device and releases a fresh new interface for phones with Windows phone 7.
Social investments mark this year, with the purchase of Skype, the video and voice chat service.

Microsoft purchases Yammer, the enterprise social networking service. This year also sees the release of Windows 8 with a new user interface, and the first Surface laptop to go with it. After 30 years, the employees giving campaign tops one billion dollars.

Office Home Premium launches and hits the one million subscriber mark 100 days later. Also in July, Steve Ballmer announces the “One Microsoft” realignment designed to enable innovation across teams. In the same year, the Xbox One is revealed to the press in May and ships in November.

This turns out to be a bumper year for announcements and releases… In February, Satya Nadella, a Microsoft veteran, is named its third CEO. In March, the new Office for iPad is announced along with a commitment for Microsoft applications to support both Apple iOS and Google Android operating systems. In April, Microsoft completes the acquisition of Nokia Devices and Services and introduces Cortana, a digital personal assistant, along with the release of Windows Phone 3.1. In June, the Surface Pro 3 launches as a tablet that can replace your laptop and in September, Microsoft acquires Stockholm-based Mojang and its blockbuster Minecraft franchise.

July sees the release of Windows 10, which was built from the ground up to power a cloud-first world. In the Windows Devices event in October, Microsoft announces Surface Book, Surface Pro 4, Band 2 and two Lumia phones with Continuum.

In January, Microsoft philanthropies commits to $1 Billion in donations putting Microsoft Cloud to work for global good. Microsoft announces formation of a new AI and Research Group in September. In October researchers achieve human parity in conversational speech recognition. At the Windows Creator event Update announcement in October, a host of new products are announced, including the Surface Studio and Dial, and the acquisition of LinkedIn is finalised in December.

March brings the announcement of the general availability of Microsoft Teams, a new chat-based workspace. In June, the Surface Laptop and new Surface Pro become available in 25 markets worldwide. In November, Microsoft announces an ambitious modernisation project for their Redmond headquarters, with 18 new buildings to be completed by 2022.

A product that began as a 2015 hackathon project ships in May: The Xbox Adaptive Controller, designed to include gamer’s of all abilities. The Surface Go also launches, offering a new level of portability and affordability to consumers. In October, Microsoft finalises the acquisition of GitHub, with the goal of empowering developers, accelerating GitHub’s growth and advancing Microsoft’s services with new audiences.

Originally launched in June 2017, Microsoft expands Xbox Game Pass to include new releases from Xbox Game Studio. Xbox Game Pass and Game Pass for PC gives gamers unlimited access to a library of over 100 video games with new titles added regularly.

Xbox series X is announced at the Game Awards in December for the upcoming 2020 holiday season. After eighteen years and Three console generations, the Xbox takes another leap with its most powerful and gamer-centric console ever.

On June 24, 2021, Microsoft announced Windows 11 during a livestream. The announcement came with confusion after Microsoft announced Windows 10 would be the last version of the operating system; set to be released in Fall 2021.[148] It was released to the general public on October 5, 2021.
On January 18, 2022, Microsoft announced the acquisition of American video game developer and holding company Activision Blizzard in an all-cash deal worth $68.7 billion.
